narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: read the works of great sociologists. learned the origin and meanings of modernism and post-modernism in various applications.
How to analyze texts from various disciplines I have little experience in.
I had a solid introduction to foundational voices/theories of sociology, specifically as it pertains to the 20th century and notions of modernity.
I had never theorized anything like I have during this past semester. It was a true skill I have developed and I am very thankful to this class for that.

I learned to grapple with sociological texts that are broad, dense and sometimes quite difficult, be able to come up with examples in my life that resonates with the texts, bring to discussion in class, and most importantly build connections between different texts to understand modernity and the modern life holistically.
Almost a beginner sociology class

From this course, I developed a more analytical lens by which to read classical sociological texts and traced the arc of sociological thought on themes from truth, civility, modernity, stability, etc. This course provided insights on and questioned the foundations of our current world and by focusing on objects such as the sword, fork, clock, etc. we kept our conversations grounded and accessible for anyone to participate in.

I didn't know anything about sociology coming in, and was grateful for what I learned in this course! I learned the framework for sociological thinking, got exposed to some of the main sociological thinkers, and overall learned about this field which I was unfamiliar. I thought all the class discussion were very interesting, and covered a lot of ground.
Reading dense sociology texts, participating meaningfully in discussion, everything about the development of modernity through a sociological lens.

-learned about many sociological concepts and thinkers
-improved on my discussion skills
-learned how to lead a class discussion

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: professor adams, reading materials
weaknesses: none!
Very interesting readings, flexible discussions, engaging questions.
No weaknesses! Loved this course

Strengths: topic was extremely interesting and invites lots of different ideas, Prof Adams is simply amazing and one of the kindest person I've ever met.
Weakness: sometimes the readings are too long and it is clear that most people did not read it, and discussions become relatively peripheral or surface level. So ideally there could be fewer readings during some weeks which ensures the depth of the discussion, and Prof Adams could intervene or guide the discussion more.
Interesting materials, and the professor is really kind and engaging. The discussions can sometimes be dull, but maybe it's just because it's a 9am.

One of the greatest strengths of this course is the selection and order of the texts. By picking engaging and thought-provoking texts in a somewhat chronological order, we were able to continually make connections between the texts and expand our understanding.

I liked the blog set up of the course, the format for class discussions, and the variety of the texts we read. My main complaint was that the volume of reading was too much to possibly read, so I often felt so overwhelmed I would end up reading less than if there was just less reading. If the readings were a little more contained/less I feel like I would be able to focus in more and offer more to class discussions!

Strengths are the professor, the content, and the blog post format. Truly there are not many weaknesses of the class. I think that although the turnaround for blog posts is tight (pretty much within 24 hrs of the leader's post), it keeps the class engaging because we can reference each other's posts during class and was personally a nice accountability mechanism.
Weakness may be that the reading quantity is pretty substantial. As in, after the first week we frequently were assigned over 200 pages per week--this means there's often a lot of content to cover during discussion, which might not directly reference the reading as well. I think the work is still very manageable, though, but I probably could have skimmed less and read them more in depth throughout the semester if not for it being easy to push doing the readings over the weekend + balancing workload from other classes.

strengths:
-the readings were interesting
-the professor was clear and organized

weaknesses:
-the readings were too long
-the class structure was the same every time which led to a disengagement

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES YES YES!!! this is the best seminar I've taken at yale.
Yes, this is such a fun course where you also learn a lot.

Absolutely, regardless of your interests I recommend this class. I actually think the class is made better through the inclusion of non-sociology majorsit was so exciting to hear the perspective of students in different disciplines. Professor Adams is amazing. Not only is she a fantastic instructor and deeply passionate about the material, she is abundantly kind.
100% Julia Adams is a fantastic professor!
yes!

YES! It s an excellent way to learn about sociology and modernity regardless of your level of familiarity with the discipline. There really is no barriers of entry, and what you make out of it depends a lot on your personal interest and level of engagement. It is a relatively low stakes way to learn about works by arguably the majority of the most important thinkers in sociology, and at the end of the course you would feel like "modernity" seems to be more under your grasp!
Yes!

This class is very well-organized and well taught, so if you are willing to critically engage with the texts and the in-class as well as the blog discussions, there is truly a lot to gain from this class.
I would! I think it's a fun and engaging course, where you will learn and think a lot. And Professor Adams is the kindest!

Yes; Prof Adams so welcoming and great at leading discussion. The work is engaging but not stressful, and there is so much to gain from the readings and discussion with other students in the class. The scope of the course--a things leading to modernity--feels really broad at first, but over the course of the semester I think the readings and discussion eventually narrow our focus of things to some common topics / throughlines, which is really cool experience.

I would only recommend this course to another sociology major. I think it is interesting to anyone but most relevant to sociology majors. I think if you're not interested in the material you could become disengaged by the class structure.
